title: Drop Spindle, for making yarn from raw fiber

description.text:
Update 1/11/15: included a version 2.0 of whorl (wheel part).  Also included a new .scad file so you can tweak this new version yourself.  
Update 1/5/15: I fixed a problem with the wheel file.  No longer has an embossed name on it and should print with no errors.  
Drop spindle based on an 8mm shaft size.  You may need to do some hand tooling after printing for perfection.  The inside hole of the whorl may need to be reamed out to fit the spindle.  The idea is to use a piece of filament with some glue or acetone mix to glue the two halves of the spindle together.  This is so you can print the pieces (3) on a small work bed.  You will need to use "supporting material" in order to print a cylinder shape lying flat on the work bed.  You will need to drill out with a 3mm drill bit the supporting material so you can insert some filament to bind the two spindle sections together.  If you have questions, let me know.  Please feel free to use, modify, improve etc this design.  Sheep, wool, fiber, spin, spinning, alpaca, whorl, drop, spindle etc.

An expansion wedge for securing a bolt within a tube, inspired by the quill stem of a bicycle. This model is customizable for your specific dimensions. It should be printed at high density (or solid) since it is meant to be pressed between two metal nuts. The default values will fit a 3/8" bolt and nut inside of 3/4" EMT conduit. By using an eye bolt on each end of a length of conduit, you can make a sliding curtain rod. (That's right, the entire rod, not just the curtain.) I have 2 conduit rails hung below the ceiling of my garage, 2 gliding rods between them, and a plastic drop cloth attached with shower curtain rings. This setup gives me a fully enclosed dust curtain that I can slide in and out easily. USE CAUTION WHEN HANGING THINGS OVERHEAD. Obviously this system will not bear loads greater than a few pounds. You might hang a utility lamp or other lightweight object but definitely do not let children play or hang on these rods. There are of course many applications for these other than what I've described, and I'd love to hear about how you might use them! Notes about this model:

  • This design capitalizes on the fact that the two surfaces which are meant to slide against each other are those which adhere to the build plate. The flatness of the first layer reduces the friction of the interfacing parts.

  • The center hole is slightly flared to accommodate angular deflection when wedged. So it may appear ovalized and feel wobbly but this is desired.

  • In Customizer, the units are in terms of diameter (not radius) since the typical scenario would be someone measuring their actual application's dimensions using a caliper.

  • I can't believe this thing wasn't here already.

Print at high density or solid. This part will be pressed between two metal nuts.  
No need for raft or support since the overhang is 45 degrees. If you desire several sets, I recommend printing one set at a time to minimize warping caused by cooling reaction. Warping may disengage the part from the bed and fail the print.   
Do not put the part into service until it is completely cool. The pressure may deform it. Periodically check the part for tightness once it is in service.

comments.author: Nianzu

comments.text: I was inspired by thingiverse.com/thing:15149, which is two pieces that you have to screw to a wall at the right distance. So what I did was really just a remix-ish of his idea. He doesn't have a copyright on the idea, so neither should I. But if you intend to distribute it for money, be kind enough to pass a few bucks my way to help fund my other 3d printing projects that are in development :)
comments.author: Nianzu

comments.text:
when you posted it - did you select creative commons license?
you might want to google that.
comments.author: sketchpunk

comments.text: I picked the same license I use for all my projects, the non-commercial cc. I usually do because I don't feel that people should make money off any of my work if I'm not willing to do it. But this is the internet, things get nabbed and used without consent all the time. I personally don't have the time or money to pursue anyone who breaks the license, so all I can ask is if you're gonna generate some cash of my ideas, the right thing to do is to at least give me a small slice. But in the end, if Nianzu does make money off this design, I'm not expecting to see a single fraction of a cent. If I was hardcore about making cash off my ideas, I wouldn't post things like this on thingiverse along with all the original source.

This is an adjustable sun visor extender that I made for my short wife when the sun is low in the sky.  
It has clips which slide onto a frame and the visor is adjustable in steps.  It is 10" long and 5" high. The clips are rather large, but they are pretty strong and won't slip (from my intial testing).  
There are two small holes in the adjustor arm for a loop of string, or a piece of filament so you can easily pull the adjusting arm out of the hole it is seated in (a piece of filament can be riveted in by melting the back side).  
The holes in the visor are just to keep the piece from sticking too aggressively to the printer bed.  
This thing will probably warp in the summer, but I guess I'll find out then.

Print it. I used 20% infill.  
Scale it down if it is too big.

title: Qi Wireless Charger for Nexus 5 and 4 (and others)

description.text:
This wireless charger fits the Qi charging circuit available from Adafruit Industries (https://www.adafruit.com/products/2162) and is sized for a Nexus 5 and 4 and should work for other phones that support wireless charging as well. The charging shelf is covered in fabric that is held in place by a ring on the outside shelf edge. Parts needed:
One 100mm x 150mm piece of thin fabric
Two 3mm nuts
Two 3mm x 15mm screws
One Adafruit Qi charging circuit linked above Edit Jan 12 2015: I made a minor adjustment to the shelf, widening the wire gap to account for different soldering on different Adafruit boards. The previous design worked but may have require a small plastic trim which is not longer required.

1) Print Wireless Charger Shelf.stl.
2) Print Wireless Charger Base Bottom.stl.
3) Be ready with two 3mm nuts.
4) Print Wireless Charger Base Top.stl.
5) When printing the top, pause the printing on the first layer that looks like the photo attached to this project, and insert the two 3mm nuts into the print as shown.
6) Press the charging coil into the square recess of the shelf.
7) Place the fabric on the shelf and snap the outer ring into place. (you may wish to use an adhesive to keep it in place as well.) Cut holes in the fabric for the two aligning pins on the shelf.
8) Press the shelf into place on the base bottom. The charging circuit board should now also fit into place in the base bottom.
9) Feed the two 3mm x 15mm cap screws up through the base and through the holes in the circuit board.
10) Press the base top into place and tighten the 2 cap screws.
11) Optionally put something soft on the base, even a few strips of electrical or Kapton tape.
12) Charge wirelessly -_-

author: Plasticanuck

description.text: Standoff posts for mounting printed circuit boards outside of cases.

I have one of the FTDI EVE F800B boards and I wanted to do some software for it but I don't have a case. These standoffs have a small pilot hole in them, I used a #43 drill to drill it out so that I could 'tap' in some 4-40 BHCS machine screws to mount to the display. Some more of the same standoffs are used to mount a Nucelo board (the processor side) next to the display board.  
The way I am using these is to first attach them to my boards, then arrange the boards on a scrap piece of polycarbonate sheet. When the group is correct I put glue on the standoffs and glue them to the sheet. I can unmount or re-mount the circuit boards by removing the 4-40 screws.   
By having the various boards I'm working with arranged in this way, it keeps things like wires between them from being pulled off or tangled, and I can move the whole setup without worrying that the disparate boards will fall into a jumble. If you want you can even mount the plastic sheet on a wall.

remixed_from.title: Robo3D Y-axis smooth rod upgrade for stock bed REMIX

title: techno_hippieGuy's Robo3D Smooth Rod Upgrade for 495mm Rods (REMIX)

description.text:
EDIT: Sorry, completely forgot about the camera parts. I've uploaded the .stl files for both mount styles, along with the connector for the gopro style. They come from these designs: GoPro Style:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:192364 Standard:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:239268 EDIT: And the bed retaining plate, haha. Sorry, been sick, sleeping a lot, little out of it. Should have all the parts now.

So I really liked this design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:439036 But I needed more out of it. The rods I purchased were 495mm long, and I didn't want to deal with cutting them, so I took this and extended it a bit to fit. I'm also setting up an Octopi controller with a raspberry pi. So I integrated a camera mount with a slot for the ribbon. There is also a second style of mount in case you end up printing a taller object. I'll be including an extension arm soon which will raise the height of the camera. It hasn't been measured for standard gopro mounts, but I'll get a small adapter arm for one of those as well. Lastly, I just copied over another belt attachment so that both sides of the bed can be held at the same tension. I've been having issues where the right side of the bed would slide loose a bit and the bed would be able to jiggle. A second belt should prevent this from happening.

So this is pretty easy. You'll need: -2x 495mm M8 Smooth Rods: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0045DWA9C/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
-4x LM8UU Linear Bearings: http://www.amazon.com/Easy-RepRap-Linear-Bearings-Printer/dp/B00ED150S4/ref=sr_1_1?s=industrial&ie=UTF8&qid=1420200644&sr=1-1&keywords=LM8UU+linear+bearings
-2x 525mm (approx.) GT2 Belts : http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00FM5SC2Q/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s02?ie=UTF8&psc=1 (I just picked this up, comes with 1150mm of belt and 2 pulleys.)
-4x M3x40mm(+) screws, I prefer hex heads, less likely to strip, for bearing mounts
-8x M3x15mm screws
-6x M3x25mm(+) screws, I prefer hex heads, less likely to strip
-10x M3 nuts or lock nuts (For both of the above, you can double if you plan on printing 4x retaining plates, as there are spots for 4, 2 to hold the bed down, and 2 for decoration. I'll be adding a few different designs in time, but as for now I just want it to be functional) Process: -Remove current bed assembly
-Screw bearing mounts into existing holes
-Tighten with nuts/lock nuts underneath printer
-Insert bearings, place top mount, screw in using M3x15mm. DO NOT OVER-TIGHTEN, or you will strip the plastic and bearings will not stay in place. I want to integrate nuts into the design at a later date to ensure top piece stays in place
-Take the 525mm (approx.) belts and insert into holders on the rear bed mount. Secure with zip tie.
-Insert rods through bearings and press fit into back mount.
-Attach front mount to rods, press fit. Take the belts and insert to belt mounts, and again secure with zip ties.
-Place bed into mounts and secure with retaining plates. I'd recommend cutting a hole in the front of the printer and moving the cables to go through there. I had some issues with my old heater, so when I replaced it, I re-positioned it so that the cables pointed towards the front. I still feel I need to make a clip for the cables to help with strain relief, so that will come eventually. It's a much easier build than it appears on initial inspection. Good luck!

description.text: This may seem like almost a no design because of its simplicity, but it is fully functional.  I re-use the cardboard packaging boxes that come with the many things I order online.  They're usually quite strong and are ideal for keeping stuff like pencils, craft hand-tools, and other small stuff.  But as I access the contents frequently, I don't want to have to seal the box every time, to avoid the flaps from remaining open.  So I have created this closure clip which slides in between the two longest flaps and holds the box closed without sealing it.  The bigger or longer the box, the more clips can be used.

The 4mm clip will accept up to 3,5mm thick card and the 7mm clip will accept up to 6.5mm thick card.  Just print it and then slide into position.  I recommend using at least two clips to close the box.

title: High velocity fan duct for Velleman Vertex K8400 25mm extruder fan

description.text:
"High velocity" = narrow exhaust = higher air velocity (maybe)
Wide area version available. NOTICE! This duct limits Y axis by ~25-30mm. Do not crash your machine!

Use on your own responsibility and if you see it is usable :)
There's a minor problem with the STL but it printed pretty nicely though! Print orientation: fan mounting side on bed
Standard Velleman Vertex K8400 print profile (Cura, 0,2mm layer) To mount:
Drill fan holes to 3mm
Make M3 threads on the fan duct holes
Bend 25mm fan holder clip upwards parallel to print bed
Use 12-16mm M3 bolts for mounting

comments.text:
This fan is not specificly for cooling down your printed layer, it is more to keep the isolator guide cool (so you filament stays hard until the heat block.
More over: cooling that close to the heated bed will reduce adhesivity of the first layers.
comments.author: Jeedee23

comments.text:
You are absolutely right! The fan was originally intended for peek isolator cooling. However for that purpose it was totally useless from the beginning! :D
Nevertheless, I have not used this fan duct for years as I noticed no real improvement on print quality.

author: oliverjenks

description.text: The Yakovlev Yak-30 was an experimental Soviet interceptor from the late 1940s. Derived from the Yak-25, from which it differed primarily in having wings sweptback 35° at quarter chord, the Yak-30 retained the fuselage, tail surfaces and undercarriage of the earlier fighter fundamentally unchanged. The Yak-30 was designed to meet a Soviet requirement for a fighter capable of Mach 0.9, and able to operate from existing unpaved airstrips. To meet this request required a sweptback wing. Yakolev based their design on the existing Yak-25 experimental fighter, but incorporated a modified wing with a sweep of 35 degrees. If you like this model then give it a like. Don't forget to visit our site http://www.creationengineering.co.uk for further information on our technology, research and creations. Don't forget to follow us on Twitter @bioprinting2 for further information on creation updates.

comments.text:
Its very badly designed, whoever made it didnt understand the equations involved. Its very badly lopsided; makes for a violent release (inaccurate). The connectors are not properly placed, nor are they properly spaced. Cams have to be tuned for your bow. If you dont understand geometry, trig and force equations, please dont release stuff like this. Some idiot is gonna download it and think you knew what you were doing and get injured. Even with carbon fiber PLA, this thing is dangerous. I just ran it through diagnostics in CAD, no bueno my friend.... It was a valiant attempt, but if youre new to this, i recommend you copy existing designs and go from there, theyre patented for a reason bud. This is no "toy", please use your head when designing something that has the potential to seriously injure someone. And no, just because it fits into a bow, doesnt mean it works. lol.... Its not that simple.
See how theres cuts in weird spots on the original? Those are there for a reason, you have to balance it. Use a material density calculator and set your displacement geometry accordingly. That will stop the violent releases.

If you are unfamiliar with the slicers or CAD, you really shouldnt be printing, and defiantly not a weapon. You are going to hurt yourself, bad, kid. Please learn what youre doing and how to print structural parts before even attempting them. Compound bows break aggressively, this isnt a toy. You also need to know how to print exotic filament. You will need fiberglass polycarbonate or carbon fiber PLA. Your printer may not even be up to the job. Its a very hot and very difficult filament to master and takes a few rolls to learn. I highly advise against cutting the model; if its too tall for your printer, in this case, its dangerous to cut and glue. But before you do any of this, you need to learn the software....

This is a leg pair, derived from Theo Jansen's Strandbeest, that is compatible with LEGO Technic. I built a set of these to give to my six year-old, who is pretty excited about robots and our 3D printer. Combined with two LEGO Technic motors, some geartrain parts, and the LEGO IR remote, this becomes a walking robot. I assembled this as a steerable robot with the drive train in the center, and three leg-pairs on each side. The LEGO remote can drive two motors, so I set it up with one motor driving each side, so that the bot can be steered like a tank. Here's a short video, narrated by my 6 year old: http://youtu.be/0TVsqX-lvMk

To make a walking robot, you will need six leg pairs. The Strandbeest leg pairs are very fun to watch walk, and though the leg assemblies in each pair are symmetrical, their movements are not! The leg pairs are modular, and they snap together with four snap pins, and an indexed shaft. This allows a modular assembly that carries the crankshaft through each leg pair. The crank washer detail image shows the position of the washer (grey in the image) in between the connecting rods and the crank disk. The gait of the Jansen legs is designed so that three leg pairs are the equivalent of one wheel. So my design has you coupling the leg pairs at 120 degrees from one another. To make a complete walking bot, you will need six leg pairs (twelve legs). I will put together some parts plates soon to simplify this. You will need to print (per leg pair): 1 ea Body Back Shell
1 ea Body Cap
1 ea Body End
1 ea Crank
2 ea PelvisHipA
2 ea PelvisHipB
2 ea KneeFootA
2 ea KneeFootB
2 ea PelvisToC
2 ea BackOfLegToC
4 ea KneeToHip
4 ea Claw-Grooved
1 ea Washer There is also some hardware, and of course some LEGOs required to make this work. Specifically, you will need some Technic (the blocks with holes through them) parts, indexed shafts (48 mm, black or grey with a + shaped profile), and several little black snap pins. A pair of motors, some gears, and the IR remote go really well with this! I will upload a photo of this group of required parts soon. I have work to do on the part names. These are derivative of the way they are named here: http://geogebrawiki.pbworks.com/w/page/11911516/Strandbeest The geometry of each leg is comprised of two right triangles (actually two triangle sandwiches), and two identical struts that form a parallelagram between the two triangles. The points of the upper triangle are the pelvis, hip, and Point A. The points of the lower triangle are the Knee, Ankle, and Foot. I'm sure this will be confusing, but refer the the site above for an explanation. Point C is where all the connecting rods attach to the crank with the indexed LEGO shaft. These files should be printed with 0.35 mm layer heights. The Z axis dimensions are all multiples of this number so that you can get very close to a LEGO-compatible dimension in all axes. I use a Printrbot+ with a 0.5 mm nozzle, and I have printed this in ABS. I used 25% honeycomb infill with two skin layers with good results. For strength, orient the long parts on your print bed so the grain of the skin layers is diagonal compared to the long axis of the part (my printer will do this if the parts are aligned to the Y axis). The + shaped holes for the indexed shafts are a tight interference fit, and the larger round holes should provide a running fit on those shafts. When you go to assemble the crank disk in the body back shell and body cap, you may have to do some cleaning of the parts with simple hand tools. A small amount of synthetic bicycle grease inside this assembly really helps keep this running smoothly. There are so many points of friction in these assemblies that you need to pay close attention to how tightly you assemble the joints. It all adds up. But so does the slop, so don't go too loose either! This is designed to be assembled with 6-32 hardware. Some of the parts have "A" or "B" in their names. You'll see that the "A" types have holes that give a slip fit on the 6-32 screws, whereas the "B" versions have a sort-of self-tapping fit. In addition to the 6-32 hardware, you will need four (per leg pair - two per foot) #11 neoprene O-rings, available in the plumbing aisle of your home improvement big box. These provide traction for walking on slick surfaces. The "claw" part is meant to be secured tightly in the foot, not to roll. I just settled on O-rings for simplicity. I will upload an image of the required 6-32 hardware soon. Most of the leg assembly uses 1/2" pan head screws. The Body Cap and Back Shell are held together with 3/8" countersunk screws. The joint where the Back of Leg to C connecting rod connects to the Ankle (third angle on the KneeFoot part) uses a 3/4" pan head, which is a little too long but it works. The Body assembly is held together with two 1 1/4" pan heads, with the heads flush in their counterbores. 6-32 hardware (per leg pair assembly):
8 ea 6-32 1/2" pan head
2 ea 6-32 3/4" pan head
2 ea 6-32 1 1/4" pan head
4 ea 6-32 3/8" countersunk Orientation of the screws (and the corresponding "A" and "B" triangular parts): The detail photos of the printed parts show the orientation of the screw heads in the leg assemblies. NOTE: these prints were a previous revision, so some parts look slightly different in these photos, but the assembly process is the same. All of the screws in one leg will go in from the same side. In the assembled leg pair, one leg is flipped. One will have all of its screw heads on one side, and the other will have its screw heads on the other side. The only part that requires support material is the Body Back Shell, due to the counterbores for the pan head screws. The small counterbores for the LEGO snap pins seem to work fine without support material. YMMV with extruder nozzles smaller than 0.5 mm.

title: Bottle Rocket Launch Tube and Snow/Ground Spike

description.text:
For the traditional German "Silvester" fireworks on New Years Eve I made a launch tube for bottle rockets including a ground spike to fix it properly.
The idea is to have a design that is semi-disposable and doesn't involve dirty glass bottles that tip over from the smallest bump in the ground. Also, the launch tube can be rammed into the ground perfectly vertical ensuring a safe ascend of the rocket.
After testing it with about 30 rockets last year I'm pretty happy with the design. There are a few things to consider, however:

  • the type of rockets that we use is usually pretty big (ca. 80 cm / 3 feet). Therefore the tube is long and relatively wide. It won't work properly with the small Chinese mini-rockets. You can try to scale the model to fit those.

  • The perimeter is small to make the printer print two walls. That thickness should suffice for regular PLA in terms of stability.

  • The ground spike has a slightly larger opening for the launch tube to accomodate printer tolerance. Try it, if there is too much space, just put some folded paper to fix or glue spike and tube together. If there is too little space, scale the tube down a tiny bit.

  • Printing the tube bottom first and the spike pointing upwards is recommended. Best results are achieved with a printed brim to keep it from toppling during the printing.

  • LOng spike is for firm snow or soft ground, short spike is for firm ground or harsh snow.

  • Recommended settings on printrbot:
    Wall: 0.8 mm, 0.4 mm nozzle, 0.3 mm layer, 210 °C first layer, 195°C remaining layers. 40 mm - 80 mm/s speed.
    • Use at your own risk! Even bottle rockets are dangerous and making this thing requires you to take all steps to ensure a safe rocket start. This tube can break if you print it improperly and it is certainly not the way the manufacturers of rockets intend to have them fired! You've been warned, I'm not responsible for any damage you cause using this thing!

comments.text: I've used them for two years now and just print new ones for this year. They really work great and make launching the bottle rockets much easier. No more messy red wine bottles with stinky leftover contents inside.
comments.author: biolippi

author: biolippi

title: Friendlier x/y belt pulley for Mendel/Huxley

description.text:
A slightly more printer friendly version of the small x and y belt pulleys found on the Reprappro Huxley and Mendel (and probably other printers that use a belt of the same type). I was having issues printing the .stl that reprappro provided because Slic3r was trying to get my printer to make two round shells and then extrude tiny, lonely drops to make the teeth.
(https://github.com/reprappro/Mendel/blob/master/Print-mendel/Individual-STLs/pulley-2off.stl) I made the teeth on the gear more pronounced by reducing the inner diameter, making it easier to get more defined teeth by convincing Slic3r to print all of the teeth in one shell.

I got the pictured results at 30 mm/sec, 3 vertical shells, .2 mm layer thickness, 150% extrude width on my .5 mm nozzle. I recommend 100% infill.
Get the extrusion temperature as low as you can get it for the teeth. My first layer was 200Â°C at .5 mm for awesome adhesion to my kapton-covered 80Â°C bed. After the round bit, I reduced it to 174Â°C, but these numbers will vary based on your printer/PLA combo.

comments.text:
That's one of the reasons I stopped using Slic3r and moved to Skeinforge.
Although Skeinforge is a little more complicated to setup right, it makes much nicer prints that Slic3r in my opinion (it won't try to make these tiny lonely drops as you call them, and it would not have any problems with the infill when the perimeters are too close)

Milling teeth for a filament drive gives a better "bite" than hobbing with a tap and ensures that the drive is perfectly round and concentric with the shaft.  The fixture allows for 24 perfectly spaced teeth.

I used a 2 mm end mill, you could also try a .070" mill for an even closer fit. http://mctinfo.net is a good source for small carbide end mills. I set the z height about 20 degrees above shaft center for a good tooth angle, you could go as high as 45 degrees.

comments.text: The mill head is vertical, I bring it in from the side to cut.  If you are looking at the end of the shaft, the end mill will be at about the 10 o'clock position, and then move horizontally into the shaft to cut.

2015-08-29 update
now support “Duet Shield”, revision some hole like jstck 's "Rear-mounted Duet enclosure for RepRapPro Ormerod 1" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:478829. and, that use Ormerod 1.0 's stl on github.com as a reference.Parameters more accurately. Note:
(1)you need to upgrade Y-axis form Ormerod1 to Ormerod2.This is necessary to adjust the vertical distance between the aluminum and the back-end.
(2)Add four M3 flat head screws, four M3 nuts, two 15mm copper cylinder, used to strengthen the fixed.

Should become a Tire, printed in Filaflex. I designed it to fit UP! Filamentspools. The Up spool-design allows to 3d-print anker possibilities in order too create axle driven wheels. Depending on wich percentage of infill is used, the tire 's density can be regulated. Follow us on twitter; https://twitter.com/3DPrintersVDB
Like us on facebook: https://www.facebook.com/3DprintersVDB

What to do with empty spools of filament? They have a center and two sides, just like rims.. So lets make some wheels.
Make sure you design the inner ring not too tight. Remember, the tire has to stay in place on the rim, but has to be fitted too.
Tip; start with the filamentspool's outer diameter and inner width of the spool.
Start calculating from there on. And remember that radius is half the diameter :)

description.text:
This is a must for any 3D printer operator. I find myself getting into situations where I have to present my 3d printer or explain what one does. Well a lot of people want to see what one can make. I usually don't have good objects to present to them or show them. I have created a fail proof pack of awesome stuff from Thingiverse to show your audience what your printer is capable of. Here are the different items:

  • Bre Pettis's Head
    Bre scanned his head on a 3D scanner then uploaded to Thingiverse.
    File Name: Bre_DI3D_Sample10k-fixed.stl

  • Whistle
    Zaggo created this awesome useful whistle that actually works. A favorite among my friends.
    File Name: whistle_v2.stl

  • Whale Tooth
    Vik created this sperm whale tooth. Because sperm whale teeth are very rare. But with a 3D printer there is now an abundance of them.
    File Name: whale_tooth.stl

  • Bottle opener
    Starno created this bottle opener which uses a penny to open a bottle. A favorite among men. Instert a penny and your good to go.
    File Name: penny_opener_cut.stl

  • Elliptical Gears
    Natetrue designed these elliptical gears that clip together to form a working elliptical gear set.
    File Names: ellipsegearlink.stl
    ellipsegear.stl

    Big thanks to all who all listed!! Email me if you would like to have your design on the list.

description.text:
Free Software for optimizing g-code-files (i.e. from Axon 2)
main features (NEW: Version 1.4 (10/2013)):
  • Text-view of g-code (with comments for the commands)
  • 2D-view of g-code (for each layer)
  • de-raft
  • cooler always on
  • additional z-moves (to prevent strings)
  • check printer area
  • head-cleaning (with optional brush)
    and new:
  • Edit g-code-text
  • resizeable 2D-View
  • finally send free info-SMS
    • NEW (06/2014):
  • check extruder control (e.g. does extruder heat up before printing...)

Hi,
I use Axon 2 and was not very happy with the results.
So I started to develop a little software, that is able to optimize the g-code-files (i.e. *.bfb).
The software is still experimental, but everyone can download it from: http://www.g-opti.com
The g-opti-software has the following features:
  • derafting (first 2 layers - raft has to be of different material than object!)
  • adding a 'start-string'
  • keep cooler always on
  • reduce speed of 'fast-movement'
  • add 'Z-move' whenever the extruder moves to a new position
  • add comments to all g-code-commands (expt. "G1"-moves)
  • send an SMS to your mobile phone when the optimizing-process is finished
    In future there will be these additional features:
  • setting the temperature for each of the first two layers
  • setting the extruder-rate for each of the first two layers
  • setting the temperature and the extruder-rate for the last layer
    Actually the software is only available in english and german language.
    BUT ATTENTION: the software is experimental !!! So check out the result-file to avoid damage to your printer !!!
    Everyone uses the software on his own risk !!
    Happy printing
    Bundes-Metal-Minister

remixed_from.author: murat
remixed_from.title: Quick Change Spindle for 1lb filament spool

description.text:
This is a quick change filament coil holder. I adapted it from a remix of another spool holder by KitWasHere, which he adapted from Murat. The pics are from KitWasHere and show his shorter arms which work well for small coils.  
The coils from faberdashery are too big for the original, so I made new longer hooks to fit. There is also an adapter to make it fit the spool holder on my Kossel Mini. The adapter is optional, I found the hooks caught on other bits of my printer so the adapter offsets the spool on my spool holder.  
It works really well and avoids having to re-spool the faberdashery coils or have them get into horrible tangles.

Print the spoolMain, print 2 spoolCaps, print 3 longerspoolHooks.   
You need to use 3x M3 hex bolts 18/20mm, and 3 M3 Nylock nuts to bolt the hooks to the hub. Don't overtighten they need to move when you want to change coils! Add one medium size elastic band across the 3 slots.  
Print the adapter if you need it. I found the hooks caught on other bits of my printer so the adapter offsets the spool on my spool holder.

author: Domterran

description.text: Art-deco style domed speaker grill.   As is, it makes a grill for a 55mm speaker (to fit an MFOS Noise Toaster) but you can alter everything (diameter, thickness, number of bars, dome height...) to suit.   Note that as you vary the print layer thickness, you will get coarser/finer stepping on the bevels and domed grill; this actually looks pretty good.

I printed the two examples shown on a K8200, using Form Futura "silver" EasyPLA and a 0.5mm nozzle, onto kapton.   The coarser one is printed at 0.4mm layer height and 3 perimeters, and the finer one at 0.25mm layer height and 10 perimeters.  Both had temperatures of 215C nozzle, 55C bed.  
Note that the "look" changes drastically as you change the layer height.  Feel free to experiment, the OpenSCAD file is included.

description.text: With Valentine's Day just around the corner, I'm uploading this to inspire designs for the long-suffering significant others of Makerbot owners. Greg Frost made a valiant effort at making an openSCAD heart out of primitives for his broken heart http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4683, but he wasn't satisfied with the small discontinuities, so I made this new and improved version. It's an implementation of Taubin's equation: http://mathworld.wolfram.com/HeartSurface.html.

While not printable itself, this heart is meant to be exploited for Valentine's mashup designs (in the spirit of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6078 and Makerblock's blog post). I hope to see this used in some entries to Pattywac's latest challenge: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6035. The heart is 100x100x60mm, so scale from there. It has a lot of facets, so if rendering or skeining is going slow, it might be helpful to reduce the mesh in meshlab or similar. I've also included the script I used to generate it in Matlab (which might also work in Octave, if you prefer a FOSS alternative). You'll need the surf2stl script from the Matlab file exchange, but that's a great tool for modeling anyway.

title: iPhone Stick - Kickstand for 6 plus, 6 and 5/5s with or without leather case

description.text:
Updated feb. 24th 2015:  
v2 - This one has hooks for earplugs or a headphone-cable. Also there is a more grippy surface so it won't twist as much. Caution, this might make some marks in your case (as you can see in the picture with the grey one), but I kinda like the patina the leather-case gets from use, and I really like the extra grip. Up to you, I'm not removing the original "2015ed". I've only tested it on the 6 plus, so any feedback from those of you that have the others would be appreciated.

This is my 2015 edition of the "iPhone Stick", the latest and greatest of my EDC kickstand that I use all the time. I've designed it to work with the iPhone 6 plus and 5/5s, with or without the official leather case. It should be reasonably stable both in landscape (great for video) or portrait (great for video-calling etc.). I have also added a "theoretical" iPhone 6-version that I haven't tested (I don't have one handy, it's slightly towards the 5 rather than 6+ in size and the openings are 0.2mm smaller than the 6+), so any feedback is appreciated.  
I make these to fit the original Apple leather cases, as they are my favourites, and they are quite popular. It might work with other cases as well, but I haven't tested any except one: I also designed a version for 5/5s made for a slightly slimmer case named *HT that I made for a friend (her initials).  
They work best with a case, as the iPhone is quite slippery, but depending on your print (rougher might be better for grip) and material, it should work for most "light use", which is my goal here.  
Enjoy! :)

My print is in PLA, 5 shells, 0.25mm layer height and 10% infill. This is basically a massive print, which is between 3.4 and 4.4 grams, taking 10-12 minutes at 90mm/s on a Rep2.  
v2: This one is slightly wider, hence the material-use has increased to about 4.3 to 5.5 grams, and the print time to 15-19 minutes at the same settings.  
Rotate 90 degrees on to its side for best print.

title: Spiral fractal based on an affine IFS

description.text:
A spiral fractal generated using an affine iterated functional system described on the Yale website
http://classes.yale.edu/fractals/labs/SpiralsLab/SpiralsLab.html .
It's really a 2D fractal but I use a box-shaped initiator and show the iterations progressing upward in the third dimension.
Printed on a Form1+ at Centre College in association with a course on chaotic dynamics and fractal geometry.
Using Matlab the transformations are iteratively applied to the vertices of triangles covering the initiator cube.  The Matlab script outputs an ascii stl file one triangle at a time.

makerblock.com/2011/02/makerblock-thing-a-day/ I've put the opto-endstops back into my Cupcake! I had taken the endstops out because they weren't necessary for normal safe operation and tended to get a little cumbersome. However, in the hopes of creating some auto-homing GCode, I've re-installed them. At best I had a very jury rigged endstop trigger. This is intended as a workable fixture. Day 6: Cupcake CNC Optoendstop Trigger for X Minimum http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6191
Day 5: Things That Cannot Be Unseen. thingiverse.com/thing:6097
Day 4: Extruder to Stepper mounting plate. thingiverse.com/thing:6106
Day 3: A shelving unit bracket. thingiverse.com/thing:6001
Day 2: A mirror bracket. thingiverse.com/thing:6000
BONUS THING: A Helen Weight. thingiverse.com/thing:6024
Day 1: A bathroom hook. thingiverse.com/thing:5999

• Print.

title: Z-Axis Connector for 3/8 ACME Threaded rod

description.text: These connectors are for use on 5mm output shaft steppers and 3/8" ACME threaded rod.

1) Print
2) Insert 5mm nuts into nut capture slots on bottom of the part. Start M5 x 10 SHCS into nuts
3) Clean up ACME threads if necessary- I used a short section of ACME rod scrap chucked into a drill
4) Assemble.
5) tighten M5x10 SHCSs to fasten to stepper. If necessary a couple drops of epoxy could be used to lock ACME rods into place, I've been running my printer with no adhesive to lock the connectors to the ACME rod. Friction alone seems to be enough.

description.text:
I'm brewing beer, but my fermenter tap is leaky. It's not a big deal, but it'd be nice if it were fully watertight.


So I designed and printed a plug to stopper the tap.


It works better with tape wrapped around the plug for a smoother seal. PTFE tape would probably be best, but kapton tape seems to work OK.


I've included the solidworks source file. The dimensions might need altering for differently calibrated makerbots, since it's a tight tolerance.

comments.text: Nice.  Rather than having a smooth stopper, perhaps giving the plug a few horizontally running rings around the stopper would help with the seal?
comments.author: EverydayInventors

comments.text: Thanks. At the resolution it's printed at, the makerbot tends to add rings up the stopper anyway! However, a better design might incorporate a groove to seat a rubber washer or two, which would seal better than hard ABS plastic.

My more or less usefull attempt to recycle the batteries of Impossible Filmpacks, inspired by the original Polaroid 600 Radio: http://www.radiomuseum.org/r/unknown_polaroid_600_plus.html
but you can use all kinds of Impossible Filmpacks, u just need to take out the battery ;)

My more or less usefull attempt to recycle the batteries of Impossible Filmpacks, inspired by the original Polaroid 600 Radio: http://www.radiomuseum.org/r/unknown_polaroid_600_plus.html
but you can use all kinds of Impossible Filmpacks, you just need to take out the battery :) Additionally you'll need some radio electronics. I used this christmas calendar my son got this year:
http://www.conrad.de/ce/de/product/1225952/Adventskalender-CE-UKW-Radio-Adventskalender-2014-ab-14-Jahre
It has all nessesary electronics and a breadbord where you can try it out. After i was happy with the results i soldered everything on a protype board, but you can do it nicer of course ;)
The colors were my sons choice, so dont blame me for that (its glow-in-the-dark green, so thats cool!!! ) ;) The radio electronics are made for 3V operation, but the filmpack batteries are 6V, so i used a 3.3V Traco Voltage regulator i had lying around, which is well within the specs of the BK1068 radio IC of 2.0-3.6V (http://www.ak-modul-bus.de/stat/bk1068_breakout_board.html)
I also used some flat buttom switches i had left over and some silver plated copper wire (0.8mm). But you can use any kind of switches you like, there is plenty of room in this radio. To make contact to the batterypack i invented a solder less battery clip using some of the silver plated copper wire. For this i drilled 4 holes at the appropriate position in the battery clip and passed the wire through them. Once youre done, you glue the battery clip with some acetone to the backside of the radio at the right position. Check it together with the battery and also see the pictures i took. When everything done correctly you can simply replace the battery by pulling out the battery from the top of the radio, and lide in a new one (also a way to switch it off, so no need for an extra off switch ;) )
I added an LED and a standby touch switch on top of the Radio. Have Fun and please ask if you have questions...

title: GoPro/SJ4000 mount for German Reprap NEO 3D-Printer

description.text:
english:
I remixed the GoPro-connector a little bit. With this piece, you can mount a GoPro or, in my case, a SJ4000, to the upper right side of your German-RepRap-NEO-Printer.
I did a timelapse with a shot every 20 seconds:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mg5jIxamqyE&list=UUNEN-a8E8qiwZ0k7OBRAhxw deutsch:
Ich habe die normale Gopro-Halterung etwas angepasst. Dieses Teil ermöglich die Montage einer GoPro oder, wie in meinem Fall, einer SJ4000 an den Gewindelöchern oben rechts am Gehäuse. Ich habe ein Zeitraffervideo erstellt, bei dem ich alle 20 Sekunden ein Bild aufgenommen habe (Link: siehe oben)

title: Dial indicator holder for print-bed calibration (da vinci 1.0)

description.text:
A simple holder for a dial indicator to optimize, improve and simplify print bed calibration. this may be useful in case of FW change (i.e. in case of daVinci stock FW to repetier or octoprint), or if automatic calibration or the paper variant is not sufficient enough ...  
If you use my thing i'm not responsable for your faults or occuring damages. You may damage your printer and measuring device, or wathever you use and may loose your warranties.

Printed in ABS without special parameters (fast-preset). It depends on your needs and optical quality claims if you use support option. Mount all together on printer axis and do the calibration like in various videos on youtube (searchfor "printer dial indicator")
